Expectation1: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation1: They face a serious situation that directly tests their commitment to Christian morals
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A surprise, tie-breaking vote on a critical piece of legislation is happening in the next hour, and you must immediately contact the undecided representative.
Story: I sat in the church office, my Bible open on the desk, when my phone buzzed with an urgent message from the activist group. The legislation we’d been fighting for—one that could bring justice to so many—was coming to a surprise vote. The outcome would hinge on a single, undecided representative, and I was the only one with a personal connection. The group expected me to call, to use every persuasive tool I had, even if it meant bending the truth or making promises I wasn’t sure I could keep. But as a Christian, I was taught to value honesty, to let my “yes” be yes and my “no” be no. The pressure from my activist friends was intense; they needed me to act now, to do whatever it took. My heart pounded as I stared at the phone, torn between my commitment to truth and my desire to help those who desperately needed this law to pass. The seconds ticked by, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, demanding an answer.
